definition: to make oneself presentable/to freshen up

sentences.english: I've just been to the lavatory.
sentences.chinese: 我剛去過盥洗室梳洗了一番。

sentences.english: He dressed himself laboriously every morning and afternoon .
sentences.chinese: 他每天早晨和下午花不少工夫梳洗打扮。

sentences.english: Vacuums can a healthy, labor-saving grooming tool.
sentences.chinese: 吸塵器是一種健康省力的梳洗工具。

sentences.english: Drugstores, or pharmacies, sell cosmetics and toiletries as well as many other products.
sentences.chinese: 藥房或藥店還出售化妝品，梳洗用品及其它許多商品。

sentences.english: Finally I rise, change my clothes, and go to the bathroom to wash my face.
sentences.chinese: 天亮後，我換了衣服，到了浴室梳洗。

sentences.english: She may touch you, or display self-grooming gestures.
sentences.chinese: 她可能會觸碰你，或是呈現出梳洗打扮的樣子。

sentences.english: B:I've just been to the lavatory.
sentences.chinese: 我剛去過盥洗室梳洗了一番。

sentences.english: I wash my hair in the green waves and raise my voice in a lonely song.
sentences.chinese: 綠波梳洗我的髮際，放聲唱起一首孤獨的歌謠。

sentences.english: "Who serve what master rinse face and comb hair?"The voice of clear orchid still has some aery.
sentences.chinese: “誰服侍老爺梳洗的？”明蘭的聲音還有些飄渺。

sentences.english: This horse is wearing a grooming halter.
sentences.chinese: 圖中的馬帶了一個梳洗用籠頭。

sentences.english: A simple hairstyle can shorten your grooming routine.
sentences.chinese: 一頭短髮可以縮短你例行梳洗打理的時間。

sentences.english: Probably she had not touched her dress since yester evening.
sentences.chinese: 大概她從昨天晚上起還沒有梳洗過。

sentences.english: They were making a bit of toilet sociably together in Mrs. Baroda's dressing-room.
sentences.chinese: 在巴羅達夫人的更衣室裏，他們稍加梳洗。

sentences.english: Breakfast will be ready by the time you have dressed up.
sentences.chinese: 當你梳洗打扮好，早餐就做好了。

sentences.english: We freshened up before going to the party.
sentences.chinese: 參加聚會前我們梳洗打扮了一番。

sentences.english: A:I need to fresh up myself.

definition: to rinse the mouth and wash the face
to wash the face and rinse the mouth
to change clothes/to go to the toilet (euphemism)
to clear up/to tidy up/to pick up/to repair
to go to bed/to retire for the night
please take off your coat (honorific)/loose-fitting garment
to go to sleep/to go to bed (literary)
to have a rest/to stay for the night/to go to bed/to sleep
to attend to/to care for (patients etc)/to look after/to wait upon/to serve/also written 伏侍, see also 服事[fu2 shi4]
